Framing is key when you share your ideas at work.

Here‚Äôs a quick way to get your boss to perk up and listen:
If you dive right into sharing your recommendation, your boss won't be primed to hear it. 

They‚Äôll wonder, ‚ÄúIs this even a problem worth solving? Why does this matter?"

They won't appreciate your solution if they don't even think there's a problem.
That's why you must frame the problem, then offer the solution.

Ask yourself:

"What bad things will happen if we don‚Äôt do this? What good things will happen if we do?"

I call this the Bad Things / Good Things framework.
It helps you 

(A) structure your message in a way that makes your audience pay attention

(B) helps you give the right level of context
Let‚Äôs say you want to make changes to your homepage but your team is skeptical.

üò± What bad things will happen if we don‚Äôt do this?:

"If we don't do this, our customers will judge us for looking cringe. In the near-term, we'll continue losing visitors and wasting traffic."
ü§© What good things will happen if we do this?: 

"If we improve our homepage, we can signal the kind of brand we are. Better visuals/messaging and low-hanging fruit page optimizations will likely increase our conversion by 20% within a few months."
Most people are either driven by loss or gain.

This framework hits on both.

‚Üí When you mention what bad things happen, you appeal to the fear of loss.

‚Üí When you mention what good things happen, you appeal to potential gain. You‚Äôre painting a picture of a positive future.
NOTE: No amount of framing is a substitute for the quality of your insight or the logic behind your recommendation.

Be prepared to back up what you‚Äôre saying. Bring supporting data points, examples, and rationale. 

The bolder the claim, the higher the bar to make your case.
Strategically framing your ideas isn't only for making recommendations at work.

It drives a sense of urgency and buy-in for any audience, including leads, customers, clients, students, etc.

If you want folks to take action, you have to explain the stakes.
Takeaways:

-> If you dive right into your solution, your audience won‚Äôt understand why it‚Äôs important or urgent.

-> You must frame the problem, then present your solution.

-> "What bad things will happen if we don‚Äôt do this? What good things will happen if we do?"

Next time you think your product has a problem--stop.

It's not a bug, it's a feature.

A simple framework for turning problems into solutions: üßµ
Marketers are often put in a tight spot.

Here‚Äôs a common situation:

CEO: "We have a product launch coming up. We need you to make people want this.‚Äù

You: ‚ÄúUmm I wish you had looped me in earlier. If it had x or y feature, it would be a lot easier to market.‚Äù
But it‚Äôs too late to change the product‚Ä¶

So what do you do?

Turn bugs into features.
In engineering, a bug is an error or defect.

The inside joke is engineers will claim a bug is actually a feature. That‚Äôs often not true with software.

But in marketing, we actually CAN turn bugs into features.

The best marketers and brands do this regularly.
The things you thought were errors, constraints, or liabilities can actually become selling points.

For example, I used to think being an introvert was a bug.

I wished I were more extroverted like other leaders and founders.
By thinking introversion was a bug, I kept beating myself up & lamenting my circumstances.

But when I challenged myself to turn a bug into a feature‚Ä¶

I realized being introverted contributed to my success‚Äìit allowed me to bring a different POV in a world full of extroverts.
The goal is to see your product‚Äìor yourself‚Äìwith fresh eyes.

Features that you thought were initially bad might end up being what you emphasize.

Those features might be perfect for a specific customer or scenario.
Instead of rushing to change your product, you save time by working with what you already have.

You increase perceived value by owning the narrative.

Here are three examples:
Avis: Turning #2 into the winner

In the 1960s, Avis was the #2 car rental brand (behind Hertz at #1).

Back then, it was blasphemy to market anything but being #1 in your category. https://t.co/mw0EXnw7r4
But Avis turned the fact that they were #2 from a bug into a feature. 

They messaged that #1 brands don‚Äôt try as hard.

They said that because Avis was #2, they‚Äôd go the extra mile for you.

This frame shift caught customers‚Äô attention and built trust in Avis.
Simplehuman: Trash cans as status symbols

If you think your category is boring, try marketing trash cans.

Simplehuman, a premium trash can company, turned a basic category into a design-driven, luxury experience.

Some sell for over $150‚Äîand they have a cult following. https://t.co/hBXFIy7lF3
Ugly fruit: Defects into selling points

One-fifth of all fruit and vegetables are thrown out because of small imperfections.

This causes a lot of waste.

So a French supermarket turned a bug into a feature. https://t.co/agMLwPNTxZ
They marketed ugly fruit as quirky, irreverent, interesting.

This gave customers a story to tell when their friends came over & saw a weird apple or funky looking banana.

They repositioned a bug as a feature.

The ugly fruit was a hit and sold out faster than normal fruit.
So how do you turn a bug into a feature? Own the narrative.

If you're going to do something anyway, frame it as an intentional choice.

There are many opportunities to turn bugs into features in daily work & life:
Bug üö´: "This product is too basic. It doesn't offer enough features."

Feature ‚úÖ: "We do one thing‚Äìand one thing only: Help you get X done.‚Äù
Bug üö´: "This sucks because there are major quality control issues..."

Feature ‚úÖ: "These ceramics are hand-made, so each piece is unique and will have minor differences."
Bug üö´: "I don't want to do X. I don't enjoy it."

Feature ‚úÖ: "I could do X. At the same time, that's not highly leveraged and you mentioned wanting me to focus on Y. With Y, I recommend doing..."
Bug üö´: "Ugh. Writing a 10 page proposal is a lot of work.‚Äù

Feature ‚úÖ: "I wouldn‚Äôt want you to have to read a 10 page proposal. How about I create a 1-page summary and we can go from there?‚Äù
When you feel frustrated by the product you have to market, think about how you can turn a bug into a feature.

Is your product ‚Äútoo simple‚Äù compared to competitors?

Maybe simplicity is exactly the value proposition that a specific customer archetype is looking for.
Or vice versa.

If your product is ‚Äútoo complicated‚Äù compared to your competitors, maybe there are customers who want a comprehensive, heavy-duty product.
To apply this framework, ask yourself:

1. What do you think you have to hide?

2. Is it something you can emphasize instead?

When you have a constraint, don‚Äôt automatically look to downplay it.

Lean into it. Turn a bug into a feature.

A well-written bio is one of the best ways to show your credibility. 

But most people waste this opportunity by rehashing their resume: ‚ÄúI went to X school. I worked at Y companies.‚Äù

Instead, write your bio like it's sales copy. 

Here‚Äôs how:
You might think credibility is about working at fancy brands.

That might get your audience to perk up initially‚Ä¶

But it‚Äôs not enough to get them to buy.
If you haven't worked at fancy brands, you‚Äôre in luck.

Lots of folks with incredible bios worked at places you‚Äôve never heard of. But they are able to stand out because of one thing: 

They talk intelligently, and with insight, about their target customer‚Äôs problems.
When you speak with specificity and insight, a magical thing happens:

People assume you know how to solve the problem.

To upgrade your bio, ask yourself:

‚Ä¢ What are your spiky points of view?
‚Ä¢ What questions do people ask you all the time?
‚Ä¢ What patterns have you noticed?
Example:

üö´ Before: ‚ÄúI was a product leader for 10 yrs at X companies.‚Äù

‚úÖ After: ‚ÄúAfter 10 yrs as a product leader, I‚Äôve noticed PMs at early-stage startups struggle to prioritize bc their company strategy is evolving. I've trained hundreds of PMs to build lightweight MVPs..."
Why this works:

The ‚Äúbefore‚Äù just shows you were somewhere for a number of years.

The ‚Äúafter‚Äù shares a specific problem. When you elaborate on that problem, you show that you understand your target student‚Äôs situation.

This makes your solution (i.e. your course) more enticing.
Another example:

üö´ Before: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve led UX design at X companies for 7 yrs.‚Äù

‚úÖ After: ‚ÄúThe #1 reason UX designers don‚Äôt get a seat at the table is because they are seen as decorators, not leaders. I‚Äôve taught hundreds of designers to go from tactical to strategic.‚Äù
Why this works:

Thousands of designers have worked for 7+ years. It‚Äôs not interesting or helpful to lead with this.

Instead, start with a spiky point of view that shares insight.

Shout out to all my fellow over-thinkers...

My new year‚Äôs intention for 2023 is to worry less. I‚Äôve had the same resolution for a few years.

Here are 5 habits that helped me worry less (that might help you, too):
A few years ago, I was struck with a realization. 

In the middle of my usual cycle of worrying, a little voice inside said, 

"This thing you're worried about doesn't deserve to take up space in your head."
Because I started worrying less, I was able to:

+ Have more energy
+ Solve problems faster with more ease
+ Improve relationships because I didn‚Äôt let things fester

I want to share what I do to worry less because it could help you too.
1. When I start to worry, I remind myself to stop

This is not an exciting answer, but it's practical and honest.

There isn‚Äôt one solution that simply removed my worries.

I have to remind myself daily--and it's gotten easier over time.
2. Walking phone calls

I get antsy sitting all day.

Walking allows me to get outside, get fresh air, and get exercise while on phone calls. 

I can work for much longer while feeling energized and more balanced.
3. No notifications

I don't have notifications for anything‚Äîtexts, emails, Slack messages, etc.

You're not going to forget to check Slack. 

You probably check Slack obsessively, so without notifications, you will just check a little less obsessively.
4. No-meeting days

I'm shocked at how many people start important work at 6pm when their meetings end.

I get so much done on no-meeting Wednesdays at Maven. It's sacred time for deep work. 

On other days, I reserve 12-6pm for meetings with breaks to check Slack and execute.
5. Decide if you're going to take action

If I'm not going to take action, then the worry stays in my head.

I ask myself ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre not going to do anything about this right now, why think about it more? You can worry about this later.‚Äù
There's a difference btwn worrying vs figuring out how to solve a tricky problem.

If the latter, try articulating the issue to a partner/friend who's agreed to listen.

Verbalizing your worry can help you realize it's not so bad. You may even talk your way into a solution.

Raise your hand if this has happened to you:

You: "So how can I help?‚Äù

Stranger: ‚ÄúGreat question. Let me share some context‚Ä¶‚Äù

20 minutes of monologue later, you've zoned out and forgotten why you‚Äôre on the call.¬†

I call this backstory scope creep.

Here‚Äôs how to avoid it:
We've all been there.
 
Long-winded and meandering explanations that lead down rabbit holes‚Äîall in the name of "giving context."
 
I've been guilty of it myself.
I've been on 30-minute calls where 25 minutes was backstory.

It‚Äôs a losing situation for everyone:

As the speaker, it means less time for you to discuss the topic you actually wanted to talk about.

As the listener, you tune out because you aren't sure what to pay attention to.
So how do you avoid this?

By aiming for the Minimum Viable Backstory.

What‚Äôs the minimum backstory necessary to set the context, so you can spend time on the juicy stuff?
This isn‚Äôt easy‚Äîyou‚Äôll have to fight your urge to over-explain.

You may think the listener needs to know all the details upfront...

They don‚Äôt.

You‚Äôd be surprised how little backstory is needed to dive in.

Plus, you can always add relevant information later.
Sometimes backstory scope creep happens in team meetings where status updates take 90% of the time. You barely touch on the meaty topics.
 
How to fix:

‚Ä¢ Collect async updates in Notion
‚Ä¢ Read for 5 min in the beginning
‚Ä¢ Spend 25 minutes on the meaty topic
How does this apply to written communication?

Put your key point at the top, then context below.

Here's an example in Slack:

‚Ä¢ 2-3 lines with your recommendation, takeaway, or question
‚Ä¢ Context: Details of your thought process, rationale, risks, etc https://t.co/D0NPKNwdB2
Backstory scope creep in online courses:

Most instructors spend too much time on what the topic is and why it'll benefit students.

But often, your students already know this topic is important. That‚Äôs why they paid for your course!
 
So how do you get to the juicy stuff faster?
Think about the Super Specific How.
 
Spend 20% of the time on what & why.
 
And 80% on the how:
 
- Share a framework
- Show screenshots
- Provide a script
- Create a worksheet
- Live critique student work https://t.co/XO8ROgKjti
To be clear, sharing some background can be important.

But non-essential backstory is different from useful context.
 
Challenge yourself on whether the context is actually important‚Äîor if it‚Äôs a tangential rabbit hole.
To deliver higher ROI communication, cut the backstory.
 
And when you think there‚Äôs nothing left to cut...

Cut some more.
 
It will feel painful but you‚Äôll be surprised how much more efficient and impactful your words become.

You send a pitch email.
 
Your recipient opens your note. This is their first and main question:

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs in it for me?‚Äù

Here‚Äôs how to make sales pitches about your reader & get an enthusiastic response:
It‚Äôs normal to want to talk about yourself.

But a pitch is about your product or service *only in relation to your audience.*

This is why it‚Äôs important to put mechanisms in place to catch when you‚Äôre being too me-focused.

5 questions to ask yourself before hitting send:
1. What parts of this note mention things that mostly benefit me? What benefits the other person?
 
Your note should be 90% about the other person.
 
Trim as much of the stuff about you as possible. No one cares about you.
 
They want to know why your idea benefits them, not you.
2. What action do I want the recipient to take after they read this?

If you‚Äôre not sure, figure it out before hitting send.

Everything about your note should drive toward your goal.
3. Why would this person eagerly say yes to my request?

Make sure you include a few reasons.

If you can‚Äôt think of anything, rethink your offer altogether.
4. What might feel like a risk for my recipient?

For example, they might think,

‚ÄúThis person will waste my time‚Äù

Or

‚ÄúThis sounds like a lot of work.‚Äù
5. What signals might I be subconsciously sending?

If your DM looks like an email, you‚Äôre subconsciously showing you don‚Äôt understand DMs.

Your recipient might think, ‚ÄúThis person isn‚Äôt savvy enough to know how DMs work and will probably waste my time.‚Äù
Your audience‚Äôs default is to do nothing.

Their lives were fine before you arrived.

Their lives will be fine after you go away.

Your goal is to help them feel enough excitement about your pitch to overcome that inertia.
